description: From Middle English sippen, of uncertain origin. Compare with Low German sippen (“to sip”). Possibly from a variant of Middle English suppen (“to drink, sip”) (see sup) or perhaps from Old English sipian, sypian (“to take in moisture, soak, macerate”), from Proto-Germanic *sipōną (“to drip, trickle”), from Proto-Indo-European *seyb- (“to pour out, trickle, leak out”). Compare also Old High German supfen (“to drink, sip”), from Proto-Germanic *sūpaną (“to sip, intake”).

verbs.description: sip (third-person singular simple present sips, present participle sipping, simple past and past participle sipped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To drink slowly, small mouthfuls at a time.

examples: [She] rais'd it to her mouth with sober grace; / Then, sipping, offered to the next in place.

entries.meaning: To taste the liquor of; to drink out of.
examples: They skim the floods, and sip the purple flowers.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, US, dated) Alternative form of seep

examples: Sales of lightbulbs which sip electricity, and whose increased cost in the shops is easily paid for over their lifetime, used to double every year; in 1990/1991, they leapt sevenfold.
